sourceDesc.bibl: Letter from William Lyle Bryan to his mother, June 10,1909, William Lyle Bryan papers, Manuscript, Archives, and Rare Book Library, Emory University.

projectDesc.p: This text was created by the Lewis H. Beck Center as a part of the Oxford Experience Project. Project participants intend for this encoded text, as well as all texts produced by this project, to be made available on the web for educational, scholarly and pedagogical purposes.

samplingDecl.p: The archival material has been transcribed and encoded. Paratextual elements may be provided as digital images only, with some exceptions.

editorialDecl.p: Processing this electronic text file began by creating TIFF images of each page using either a flatbed scanner. Text pages were captured in color at 300dpi. These digital images were converted to an electronic text file by transcription. The text files produced have been proofread against the original document or a JPEG image of the original. This proofread text file has then been encoded using the recommendations for Level 3 of the TEI in Libraries Guidelines. For the details of Level 3 encoding, please see the webpage for TEI Guidelines for Best Encoding practices at http://www.indiana.edu/~letrs/tei/. Encoders silently replaced em dashes with two dashes. Page numbers and other text such as titles displayed in brackets have been added by the encoder and do not appear in the original text.

revisionDesc.change:
On 2007-10-17
Liam Ammerman and Dora Dhakal, students, Oxford College of Emory University, transcribed and encoded this document in P4.
On October 14, 2008 Alice Hickcox corrected the encoding and migrated it to P5.

div.head: [Letter from William Lyle Bryan to his mother, June 10, 1909]
div.p: We are here at Edwina's and have just gotten up. She wants us to stop over till saturday morning and I suppose I will as today and tomorrow Edwina wants us to go out to grant's Park for a little Picnic. I will then come in home and be there at 12 o'clock Saturday morning or should I get left I will be there at night. I had a good time commencement.

Out of 15 medals "nons"
won 10 and out of 4 for oratory nons got 3. The frats are defeated. We had the Honor Roll passed at commencement. I was pleased to see my name on the list. Along with three others of my class.
We had our Non reception Tuesday night. I had a fine time and met lots of the girls. We secured the orchestra that the college had hired for commencement.
The Frats couldn't get my music and had a rather dull affair.

The line was drawn closer at commencement than I have ever seen it drawn. All of the girls in town divide up and a "Frat" girl wouldnt think of going with a "Non". I was glad that Kenyon (junior) got the medal for oratory. for the "frats" ignored him though he was the best speaker and applauded the man who was phi delta theta.

postscript.p: Please keep this R. of Honor

div.head: ROLL OF HONOR
div.p: Note: A Student is put on the Roll of Honor when his yearly standing is 9 or over.
* Admitted to the Alpha Epsilon Upsilon" on an average class standing for three consecutive years of 9.25 and over.
